QuestionHeader: What  specifically  did you appreciate about the instructor’s teaching?
RawText: He always checks in to make sure students understand the material (the 'clear' or 'mud' system in particular is very helpful) and will gladly go over anything someone may not understand well. Additionally, if someone grasps the content well and is curious about more advanced topics, he is willing to take an aside to delve deeper into the student's inquiries. He rarely, if ever, directly gives an answer to a student and will instead guide them towards the correct answer until they get it. Moreover, he balances randomly picking on students and selecting raised hands and won't let a student who wasn't paying attention get away with 'I dunno' as an answer. He has a good sense of humour but also knows when to be more serious, and he is compassionate towards those who are struggling.

QuestionHeader: What aspects of this course would you like to see improved?
RawText: I would change this class to be a Quarter-long class with more learning and less throwing you into the deep end and seeing how well you thrash and flounder. The class needs to be something that builds understanding, not an exercise in how willing are you to throw your head into a wall until it stops being in the way.    Fundamentally, this class expects you to have a lot more knowledge about how to research, test, implement, and bugfix a solution to multiple complex problems. However, for me at least, those skills are not yet developed enough for this class to be a useful learning experience. Possibly pushing this class to be further out in the [ORG] degree's plans (Year 3, possibly) would be very beneficial. Alternatively, increasing the course requirement to need more foundational skills before taking the class. The difficulty would be fine at that point, it's understanding the process of getting from start to end in the project that would be beneficial.     TL;DR: Increase the course length to a full Quarter, increase the amount of in class demonstrations, and (possibly) delay this class/give it more prerequisites. The difficulty can be changed if the prerequisites or course length can't be.

RawText: I think that while programming along with the professor is good, I don't think that submitting what the class programmed together benefits the student's learning. QuestionHeader: Other Comments – giving you the space to provide additional context on why you rated any of the above INSTRUCTOR questions the way you did:
RawText: * Professor taught some lessons in ways that made the subject much less clear than it had already been. And some lessons were taught in ways that made me question if the professor actually understood the material or if he had looked it up and taken the first link google gave him. (ie a grammar lesson in place of a logic lesson because the term we were learning happens to exist in both contexts)    * I am very sure that I understand the subject matter better than the professor and that I can teach it better as well. Not just in theory. I helped several classmates to better understand the subject when it was explained poorly by the professor.    * Feedback was oftentimes timely but was sometimes delayed or entirely absent.    * Feedback was oftentimes unhelpful and vague.    * Some assignment instructions were very unclear, and when asked for clarification, an equally unclear retelling of those instructions was given, and no elaboration was given when elaboration was explicitly asked for.    * On multiple occasions the professor said they would push back the due date on an assignment but did not.    * On one occasion the professor pushed back the due date on a lengthy group assignment as promised, but within 48 hours of the original due date, the due date was moved back to the original time causing significant issues. No announcement, email, or other form of warning was given for the due date being changed back. Several days after the assignment had been due, the due date was pushed back again.    *Grading on group presentations was inherently unequal. It was stated that presentations would be partially graded based on the feedback of the rest of the class using a series of four questions. The questions used on day one were significantly different from those used on the other days, and I suspect that the nature of the day one questions would lead to much more lenient grading for the groups that presented that day than for all other groups. This is inherently unjust.

QuestionHeader: What  specifically  did you like about this course and its curriculum?
RawText: This structure of the class with the online workdays is great with the right group. If you don't have competent classmates, it leads to failure. If this structure is used again, I would as the instructor take a more personal interest in groups I deem as problematic. So that the people who are doing the work dont have their grade suffer. I understand this might take away the purpose of this class as it is a project class. But some way to encourage the less productive students, checking in on them more regularly. Some end up just needing the extra encouragement, others might need to learn that there are more serious consequences. As the 'boss' role negative feedback can be a teachable moment.

QuestionHeader: What aspects of teaching would you like to see improved?
RawText: In a capstone quarter, meetings should not be few and far between. [ORG] is meant to be a prep for EP and industry, and in neither will your boss give you vague requirements, no time requirements, and never check in. Instead of having one or two check-ins throughout the quarter and only one demo/presentation, there should be several meetings with a lot of progress reports. The meetings that are held with students should be more productive than 'How are you feeling on your capstone,' as students should be required to show their progress. This would allow the teacher to give feedback on the current state of the capstone as well as feel more prepared for the end, as they will know where they actually stand with respect to their capstone. Communication should be a lot clearer and more common between a teacher and the students in a class.
